title: Heartbreaking words of support from twin, 5, to brother as he battles 3rd brain tumour
text:

Five-year-old twins James and Joshua O'Connor have an unbreakable bond.

And for James, his brother's support is key to not only making magical family memories but also helping him fight his third brain tumour diagnosis.

Smiling proudly, the twins' mum, Chantelle O’Connor, watched her five-year-old son, James, go up to his favourite heroes at Disneyland.

As always his twin brother, Joshua, was at his side.

As the giggling boys dished out high fives Chantelle and her husband Carl filed the happy memory away with all the others they are making.

Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now

James is a real-life superhero after just finishing six months of gruelling chemotherapy, followed by six weeks of radiation on his brain and spine.

Already diagnosed with brain cancer twice before, his parents were devastated when they were told he had it a third time.

Chantelle, 31, from Lincolnshire, said: "You never expect to hear the words ‘your child has brain cancer'.

“At that moment, your entire world comes crashing down. Processing it is impossible at first. It can’t be your family, your child.

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

“But having it come back a second time and now a third time is devastating.

“It’s an aggressive cancer and we knew it would most likely return, but we didn’t think it would be so soon.”

Two years ago, Mirror Online revealed how the twins' incredible bond had helped James recover from his first brain tumour.

Aged just two he had been diagnosed with an aggressive grade three (cancerous) ependymoma brain tumour .

His parents were the first to notice something was seriously wrong when RAF engineer Carl, 32, filmed a sweet video of the twins dancing.

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

James was wobbly on his feet but he was only two so his parents weren't worried,

His symptoms of vomiting, behaviour changes and an aversion to bright lights and certain pitches of sound, were put down to reflux and he was prescribed medication.

But something was niggling Chantelle and Carl and they knew it was something serious.

They took him to Lincoln County Hospital’s A&E on February 2 2016, where scans revealed a brain tumour.

After an eight-and-a-half-hour operation which removed the whole tumour in February 2016, James endured 56 weeks of chemotherapy, which made his hair fall out and caused painful ulcers.

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

He was left unable to walk for two months and speak for two weeks but slowly recovered with Joshua’s encouragement.

Chantelle explained: "They’d snuggle up in James’ hospital bed and Joshua was so gentle with him.

"Back at home, he was the first one who got James to climb off the settee to play as he wanted to join in his brother’s fun."

But then the family were told in January last year thatJames' tumour had grown back.

Chantelle said: "We sat the boys down and explained it to them.

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

“They are very switched on and so we've always found it better to be honest but age appropriate.”

When they met with their consultant, James said: “I'm here because I need some help to get this small poorly lump out. I need a man in green to get it for me. A surgeon.’

In March 2018, James had surgery to remove the 3mm x 3mm tumour and biopsy results confirmed it was the same sort of brain cancer he’d had before.

Then Chantelle and Carl flew out with the boys to Jacksonville, Florida for nine weeks where James had proton beam therapy.

Mum Chantelle said: “It was so daunting at first but the team was amazing. We told him that he has to have some ‘special medicine’ in America.

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

“By the end of his time there, James was putting himself to sleep using the ‘special sleepy medicine’ from the ‘sleepy doctor.’”

The youngster tolerated his treatment well but his hair fell out again and he suffered terrible fatigue.

Chantelle said: "As always, James took everything in his stride with a lot of help from Joshua.

“And they loved Disney World so we made sure they had fun, too.”

Back at home in July 2018, Chantelle and Carl were overwhelmed with relief when James’ scan showed swelling due to radiation but no evidence of disease.

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

But his three-monthly routine scan in January 2019 revealed he had three new tumours at the front of his brain and a possible tumour at the base of his spine.

Chantelle said: "The boys were with us in the room when the consultant broke the news.

“They looked at the scan photos with us we explained his poorly lump had come back, along with some friends this time.

“We were clearly upset but tried to put on a brave face as we explained that we were going to try to help the poorly lumps.”

This time it was too dangerous to operate due to the tumours’ position so Chantelle and Carl explained James would need more “special medicine” – radiotherapy - which he had at City Hospital, Nottingham.

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

Joshua – who had a secret language with James when they learned to talk that no-one else could understand - didn’t miss a thing.

Chantelle said: “He asked me how the poorly lumps were going to go away if they couldn’t be cut out."

Looking at his innocent little face, Chantelle knew, as always, she had to be honest about his brother.

She said: "I had to explain that these poorly lumps might never go away now.

“But that James’ doctors and nurses would do everything they could to try and keep him and the poorly lumps OK.”

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

James finished treatment in August and the family have just come back from a week in Disneyland.

Chantelle said: “Thankfully, he hasn’t suffered too much with sickness, but he’s struggling with his appetite.

“James is also suffering a lot of fatigue, which is emotionally and physically draining.

“He finds it hard to play which is tough on Joshua as he misses his best friend and sidekick to play Super Heroes – James usually Captain America and Joshua Spiderman - and Lego with.

“But they had lots of giggles in Disneyland and also love snuggling up together watching films and Disney TV shows like PJ Masks and Mickey Mouse .

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

“And Joshua loves helping James with his colouring in.”

Since James’ diagnosis, the family have supported The Brain Tumour Charity’s HeadSmart campaign to raise awareness of children’s brain tumour symptoms and reduce diagnosis time.

The twins made a video to spearhead the campaign which has halved overall diagnosis time from 13 weeks to 6.5 weeks and aims to reduce this to four weeks or under.

Chantelle said: “It means everything to us to help The Brain Tumour Charity raise awareness.

“And we’re blessed with amazing family and friends who give us so much support.”

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

James uncle, Daniel Spink, ran the Cardiff Half-Marathon on Sundayfor The Brain Tumour Charity, inspired by his brave little nephew he calls Super James.

And in July, another uncle, Mark Green, raised over £2,000 for The Brain Tumour Charity when he cycled 310 miles from London to Paris.

James is due to have a scan this week and will get the results in a few weeks’ time.

Chantelle said: "We are hoping that radiation has shrunk the tumours and that James is stable.

“It’s a waiting game and we take it a day at a time. We’ve always been realistic but we hope for the best and live each day to the full.”

(Image: THE BRAIN TUMOUR CHARITY)

And their Super James is their role model.

Chantelle said: “James’ strength and courage keeps us all going.

“He’s taught us to make the most of every single day and that it really is the little things in life that matter the most.

“We’re are incredibly proud of both our boys – they have shown so much courage which inspires us.

“Together, we are having as much fun as possible and continue to make and cherish memories and special moments as a family.”

Sarah Lindsell, The Brain Tumour Charity’s chief executive, said: “We are incredibly grateful to Carl and Chantelle for sharing their beautiful boy’s story to help us raise awareness about brain tumours – the biggest cancer killer of children and under-40s.

“James’ courage is truly astonishing and inspirational and we are all very touched by the bond between him and Joshua."
